item.title: Link Roundup: September 9, 2024
item.description: A link roundup of articles and thoughts on practices of reading, why ChatGPT is still extraordinarily limited at writing, and the “missing questions” in our conversations about the future. As always, I generate summaries using AI and edit those summaries for accuracy and usefulness. Then, I offer some thoughts of my own. Oscar Schwartz, “Against Rereading” Link to Article Generated Summary Oscar Schwartz’s article “Against Rereading” reflects on the tension between the profound, transformative experience of reading a book for the first time and the widely celebrated practice of rereading.

item.title: What is Genre?
item.description: A concept that is has been popping up in recent posts is genre. It’s not surprising, as genre is central not only to film–increasingly, the focus of this blog–but to rhetoric and writing studies, my academic home. But what is genre?

item.title: Superheroes: Ritual or Ideology?
item.description: I read something fascinating in Rick Altman’s book that I discussed in another recent post. He talked about two ways that critics tend to look at film’s social dimension. These are as ritual or as ideology.

item.title: Masculinity in Shane and Yojimbo

item.title: Two Films on Catastrophe

item.title: Memory, Document, Archive
item.description: By collecting and categorizing historical artifacts, archives deeply influence the historical record. But they exist in complicated institutional settings, and archivists can’t always have full control over how their archives present history. Researchers have to consider the archive less as a neutral place and more as a motivated and rhetorical construction.

item.title: Satoyama, Modernity, and Tradition in Japanese Anime
item.description: I’ve been reading scholarship about anime, its history, and how it deviates from animation in the United States. It’s frequently observed that tensions between tradition and modernity are often central to anime.
